32740.meaning_1: Book 1 of the Sutta Piṭaka; Collection of Long Discourses
32740.COMMENTS: The contextual sentence shows this term being used as a title for the completed collection of long discourses. The compound analysis shows it as a genitive tappurisa (chaṭṭhī) meaning "collection of long [discourses]".

45482.meaning_1: Book 3 of the Dīgha Nikāya; Canonical Text of the Book of Travellers
45482.comments: The contextual sentence shows this is the concluding line of the Pāthikavaggapāḷi, marking the end of the text.

45480.meaning_1: the Pāthika Sutta (a discourse in the Dīgha Nikāya)
45480.comments: Named after the ascetic Pāthika who is the main subject of this discourse.

63988.comments: Refers to the story about Sunakkhatta, a Licchavi prince who became a disciple of the Buddha but later left the Sangha. The term appears in DN24 as the title of a section.

4845.meaning_1: name of a town of the Mallas; Anupiya
4845.comments: Proper noun referring to a specific town in the land of the Mallas where the Buddha stayed.

4944.meaning_1: name of a town of the Mallas; dear place
4944.comments: The contextual sentence shows this as a place name (anupiyaṃ nāma mallānaṃ nigamo). The meaning likely relates to being a "dear place" of the Mallas.

4846.meaning_1: Anupiya (name of a town); too early
4846.COMMENTS: The contextual sentence shows "anupiyāyaṁ" as a locative singular form, referring to the town of Anupiya. The word appears to be a proper noun (name of a town) based on the context.

49166.comments: The contextual sentence shows this as the name of a paribbājaka (wandering ascetic) belonging to the Bhaggava clan.

39299.construction: pati > paty > pacc + ā + khā + ti
39299.COMMENTS: In the contextual sentence, the verb is used in a dramatic renunciation scene where the speaker rejects the Buddha.

19159.COMMENTS: In the contextual sentence, "kā" is used to ask about the destination (gati) of the deceased monk, meaning "where" or "what". The form "ko" is used to inquire about his future state (abhisamparāyo), meaning "what" or "which".

571.comments: In the contextual sentence, the term refers to the Buddha's teaching about the origin of the world (lokassa samudaya). The compound combines agga (highest) with ña (knowledge), suggesting primordial or supreme knowledge about origins.

69202.comments: In the contextual sentence, visahi is used to express Sunakkhatta's inability to continue the spiritual life under the Buddha, showing the aorist form indicating past capability.

23125.COMMENTS: Refers to a specific case or legal matter involving Korakkhattiya, as mentioned in DN24

31588.meaning_2: the Thūlū people; inhabitants of Thūlū region
31588.comments: In the contextual sentence, thūlū refers to a specific ethnic group or people, with Uttarakā being one of their towns. The term appears to be an ethnonym.

48615.comments: The word appears to be a plural form referring to a tribal group, used in locative case (bumūsu) in the contextual sentence.

14668.comments: In the contextual sentence, Uttarakā appears to be the name of a place where alms were sought. The literal meaning "crossing up" may refer to a river crossing or elevated location.

23124.comments: In the contextual sentence, Korakkhattiya appears to be a proper name of a Kshatriya individual being addressed.
23124.example_1: whether he knows his own destiny.

25855.meaning_1: bent down on all fours; crawling on all fours
25855.comments: In the contextual sentence, this describes the ascetic Korakkhattiya crawling on all fours like a dog, emphasizing his extreme ascetic practice.
25855.example_1: atha khvāhaṃ, bhaggava, pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sunakkhattena licchaviputtena pacchāsamaṇena uttarakaṃ piṇḍāya pāvisiṃ. tena kho pana samayena acelo korakkhattiyo kukkuravatiko catukkuṇḍiko [catukuṇḍiko catukoṇḍiko] chamānikiṇṇaṃ bhakkhasaṃ mukheneva khādati, mukheneva bhuñjati. addasā kho, bhaggava, sunakkhatto licchaviputto acelaṃ korakkhattiyaṃ kukkuravatikaṃ catukkuṇḍikaṃ chamānikiṇṇaṃ bhakkhasaṃ mukheneva khādantaṃ mukheneva bhuñjantaṃ.

25858.meaning_1: bent down on all fours; crawling on all fours
25858.comments: In the contextual sentence, this describes the posture of the ascetic Korakkhattiya who was crawling on all fours like a dog.
25858.example_1: atha khvāhaṃ, bhaggava, pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sunakkhattena licchaviputtena pacchāsamaṇena uttarakaṃ piṇḍāya pāvisiṃ. tena kho pana samayena acelo korakkhattiyo kukkuravatiko catukkuṇḍiko [catukuṇḍiko catukoṇḍiko] chamānikiṇṇaṃ bhakkhasaṃ mukheneva khādati, mukheneva bhuñjati. addasā kho, bhaggava, sunakkhatto licchaviputto acelaṃ korakkhattiyaṃ kukkuravatikaṃ catukkuṇḍikaṃ chamānikiṇṇaṃ bhakkhasaṃ mukheneva khādantaṃ mukheneva bhuñjantaṃ.

27509.meaning_1: thrown on the ground; strewn on the floor
27509.comments: In the contextual sentence, the word describes food that has been thrown on the ground for the ascetic to eat like a dog.
27509.sutta_1: Tena kho pana samayena acelo korakkhattiyo kukkuravatiko catukkuṇḍiko chamānikiṇṇaṁ bhakkhasaṁ mukheneva khādati, mukheneva bhuñjati.
27509.example_1: Now at that time a naked ascetic who was an aristocrat of Kuru had taken a vow to behave like a dog. When food is tossed on the ground, he gets down on all fours, eating and devouring it just with his mouth.

49121.comments: In the contextual sentence, bhakkhasaṃ refers to food that is tossed on the ground and eaten directly with the mouth, emphasizing the crude manner of eating.
49121.sutta_1: Tena kho pana samayena acelo korakkhattiyo kukkuravatiko catukkuṇḍiko chamānikiṇṇaṁ bhakkhasaṁ mukheneva khādati, mukheneva bhuñjati.
49121.example_1: Now at that time a naked ascetic who was an aristocrat of Kuru had taken a vow to behave like a dog. When food is tossed on the ground, he gets down on all fours, eating and devouring it just with his mouth.

9190.construction:
na > a + √las + a + ka
alasa + ka
9190.comments: In the contextual sentence, alasaka refers specifically to a digestive disorder causing death (flatulence). This medical meaning appears to be a specialized development from the more general "inactive condition" sense.
9190.sutta_1: Yaṁ kho panetaṁ, sunakkhatta, maññasi acelaṁ korakkhattiyaṁ—sādhurūpo ayaṁ samaṇoti. So sattamaṁ divasaṁ alasakena kālaṁ karissati.
9190.example_1: That naked ascetic the aristocrat of Kuru, who you imagine to be a holy man, will die of flatulence in seven days.

21404.meaning_1: name of a group of daemons
21404.comments: In the contextual sentence, these daemons are described as the lowest class of asuras where the deceased will be reborn.
21404.example_1: so sattamaṃ divasaṃ alasakena kālaṅkarissati. kālaṅkato [kālakato] ca kālakañcikā [kālakañjā, kālakañjikā] nāma asurā sabbanihīno asurakāyo, tatra upapajjissati. kālaṅkatañca naṃ bīraṇatthambake susāne chaḍḍessanti.

48496.COMMENTS: The term refers specifically to a clump or tuft of vetiver grass (bīraṇa), which is known for its aromatic roots and used in various traditional contexts.
48496.example_1: And they’ll throw him in the charnel ground on a clump of vetiver.

17505.meaning_1: counting of days; enumeration of days
17505.comments: The contextual sentence shows this word being used to describe counting days (specifically seven days) in relation to an event. The literal meaning "one-two-days" suggests a methodical counting or enumeration of days.
17505.sutta_1: Atha kho, bhaggava, sunakkhatto licchaviputto ekadvīhikāya sattarattindivāni gaṇesi, yathā taṁ tathāgatassa asaddahamāno.
17505.example_1: Then Sunakkhatta counted up the days until the seventh day, as happens when you have no faith in the Realized One.

57773.comments: In the contextual sentence, it refers to counting seven days and nights as a unit of time (a week). The compound combines the numeral "seven" with the compound "rattindiva" (night and day).
57773.sutta_1: Atha kho, bhaggava, sunakkhatto licchaviputto ekadvīhikāya sattarattindivāni gaṇesi, yathā taṁ tathāgatassa asaddahamāno.
57773.example_1: Then Sunakkhatta counted up the days until the seventh day, as happens when you have no faith in the Realized One.

24131.comments: In the contextual sentence, gaṇesi is used to describe Sunakkhatta counting the days until the seventh day, showing the aspect of enumeration or calculation.
24131.sutta_1: Atha kho, bhaggava, sunakkhatto licchaviputto ekadvīhikāya sattarattindivāni gaṇesi, yathā taṁ tathāgatassa asaddahamāno.
24131.example_1: Then Sunakkhatta counted up the days until the seventh day, as happens when you have no faith in the Realized One.

9408.meaning_1: not believing (in); not having faith (in); not having confidence (in); not being convinced (by)
9408.COMMENTS: In the contextual sentence, Sunakkhatta is described as "asaddahamāno" towards the Tathāgata, showing his lack of faith in the Buddha.
9408.sutta_1: Atha kho, bhaggava, sunakkhatto licchaviputto ekadvīhikāya sattarattindivāni gaṇesi, yathā taṁ tathāgatassa asaddahamāno.
9408.example_1: Then Sunakkhatta counted up the days until the seventh day, as happens when you have no faith in the Realized One.

23126.meaning_1: a naked ascetic of the Korakha clan; a naked ascetic named Korakha
23126.COMMENTS: In the contextual sentence, korakhattiya refers to a naked ascetic (acela) named Korakha who is questioned about his knowledge of his own destiny after death.
23126.example_1: kālaṅkatañca naṃ bīraṇatthambake susāne chaḍḍessanti. ākaṅkhamāno ca tvaṃ, sunakkhatta, acelaṃ korakkhattiyaṃ upasaṅkamitvā puccheyyāsi, jānāsi, āvuso korakkhattiya [acela korakhattiya], attano gatinti? ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, sunakkhatta, vijjati yaṃ te acelo korakkhattiyo byākarissati, jānāmi, āvuso sunakkhatta, attano gatiṃ, kālakañcikā nāma asurā sabbanihīno asurakāyo, tatrāmhi upapannoti.

43675.comments: In the contextual sentence, the word describes the action of rubbing the back with hands.
43675.sutta_1: Atha kho, bhaggava, acelo korakkhattiyo pāṇinā piṭṭhiṁ paripuñchanto vuṭṭhāsi.
43675.example_1: Then the aristocrat of Kuru got up, rubbing his back with his hands, and said,

920.meaning_1: case of the naked ascetic Kaḷāramaṭṭaka
920.comments: This compound refers specifically to a case involving the naked ascetic Kaḷāramaṭṭaka, showing the typical vinaya usage where "vatthu" indicates a legal case or incident.

70486.COMMENTS: In the contextual sentence, "vesāliyāni" is the neuter plural form modifying "cetiyāni", meaning "the shrines of/from Vesālī". The form shows the typical -iya suffix derivation from a place name.
70486.sutta_1: sādhurūpo ayaṁ samaṇoti, so nacirasseva parihito sānucāriko vicaranto odanakummāsaṁ bhuñjamāno sabbāneva vesāliyāni cetiyāni samatikkamitvā yasā nihīno kālaṁ karissatī’ti.
70486.example_1: will shortly be clothed, living with a partner, eating rice and porridge, having gone past all the shrines near Vesālī. And he will die after losing all his fame.’

45974.grammar: ind, in comps, abbrev of api
45974.COMMENTS: In the contextual sentence, "bhaggavagottopi" shows the enclitic use of "pi" meaning "also" (the wanderer Bhaggava also sat down).
45974.example_1: nisīdi bhagavā paññatte āsane. bhaggavagottopi kho paribbājako aññataraṃ nīcaṃ āsanaṃ gahetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. ekamantaṃ nisinno kho bhaggavagotto paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca, purimāni, bhante, divasāni purimatarāni sunakkhatto licchaviputto yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā maṃ etadavoca, paccakkhāto dāni mayā, bhaggava, bhagavā.

20845.comments: The name appears to describe a physical characteristic (bucktoothed) combined with a personal name (Maṭṭaka). The contextual sentence shows this was a naked ascetic (acelo) approached by Sunakkhatta.
20845.sutta_1: Atha kho, bhaggava, sunakkhatto licchaviputto yena acelo kaḷāramaṭṭako tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā acelaṁ kaḷāramaṭṭakaṁ pañhaṁ apucchi.
20845.example_1: So, Bhaggava, Sunakkhatta went to see Kaḷāramaṭṭaka and asked him a question.

53810.meaning_1: reached the peak of fame; attained the pinnacle of renown
53810.comments: In the contextual sentence, this describes the ascetic Kaḷāramaṭṭaka who had attained the highest level of fame in the Vajjian capital.
53810.sutta_1: Tena kho pana samayena acelo kaḷāramaṭṭako vesāliyaṁ paṭivasati lābhaggappatto ceva yasaggappatto ca vajjigāme.
53810.example_1: Now at that time the naked ascetic Kaḷāramaṭṭaka was residing in Vesālī. And in the Vajjian capital he had reached the peak of material things and fame.

57795.construction:
satta + vata + pada + āni
sattavatapada + āni
57795.comments: The contextual sentence shows this refers to seven specific vows or religious practices undertaken by someone.
57795.example_1: He had undertaken these seven vows.

57796.construction:
satta + vatta + pada + āni
sattavattapada + āni
57796.COMMENTS: Refers to the seven ascetic practices undertaken by the naked ascetic Kaḷāramaṭṭaka in DN24, including lifelong nudity, celibacy, and dietary restrictions.
57796.example_1: tena kho pana samayena acelo kaḷāramaṭṭako vesāliyaṃ paṭivasati lābhaggappatto ceva yasaggappatto ca vajjigāme. tassa sattavatapadāni [sattavattapadāni] samattāni samādinnāni honti, yāvajīvaṃ acelako assaṃ, na vatthaṃ paridaheyyaṃ, yāvajīvaṃ brahmacārī assaṃ, na methunaṃ dhammaṃ paṭiseveyyaṃ, yāvajīvaṃ surāmaṃseneva yāpeyyaṃ, na odanakummāsaṃ bhuñjeyyaṃ. puratthimena vesāliṃ udenaṃ nāma cetiyaṃ, taṃ nātikkameyyaṃ, dakkhiṇena vesāliṃ gotamakaṃ nāma cetiyaṃ, taṃ nātikkameyyaṃ, pacchimena vesāliṃ sattambaṃ nāma cetiyaṃ, taṃ nātikkameyyaṃ, uttarena vesāliṃ bahuputtaṃ nāma [bahuputtakaṃ nāma] cetiyaṃ taṃ nātikkameyyanti.

36160.meaning_1: (of a boundary) does not overstep; does not cross
36160.construction:
na + ati + kama + ti
na + atikkamati
36160.COMMENTS: In the contextual sentence, nātikkameyyaṁ is used to express a vow not to cross certain boundaries marked by cetiyas around Vesālī.
36160.sutta_1: Puratthimena vesāliṁ udenaṁ nāma cetiyaṁ, taṁ nātikkameyyaṁ, dakkhiṇena vesāliṁ gotamakaṁ nāma cetiyaṁ, taṁ nātikkameyyaṁ, pacchimena vesāliṁ sattambaṁ nāma cetiyaṁ, taṁ nātikkameyyaṁ, uttarena vesāliṁ bahuputtaṁ nāma cetiyaṁ taṁ nātikkameyyan’ti.
36160.example_1: And I will not go past the following tree-shrines near Vesālī: the Udena shrine to the east, the Gotamaka to the south, the Seven Maidens to the west, and the Many Sons to the north.’

48157.comments: In the contextual sentence, this refers to a cetiya (shrine) north of Vesāli, one of four boundary markers for an ascetic's vows.
48157.example_1: tassa sattavatapadāni [sattavattapadāni] samattāni samādinnāni honti, yāvajīvaṃ acelako assaṃ, na vatthaṃ paridaheyyaṃ, yāvajīvaṃ brahmacārī assaṃ, na methunaṃ dhammaṃ paṭiseveyyaṃ, yāvajīvaṃ surāmaṃseneva yāpeyyaṃ, na odanakummāsaṃ bhuñjeyyaṃ. puratthimena vesāliṃ udenaṃ nāma cetiyaṃ, taṃ nātikkameyyaṃ, dakkhiṇena vesāliṃ gotamakaṃ nāma cetiyaṃ, taṃ nātikkameyyaṃ, pacchimena vesāliṃ sattambaṃ nāma cetiyaṃ, taṃ nātikkameyyaṃ, uttarena vesāliṃ bahuputtaṃ nāma [bahuputtakaṃ nāma] cetiyaṃ taṃ nātikkameyyanti. so imesaṃ sattannaṃ vatapadānaṃ samādānahetu lābhaggappatto ceva yasaggappatto ca vajjigāme.

65971.comments: In the contextual sentence, vatapadānaṁ refers to seven specific vows or rules of practice that led to material and fame benefits.
65971.sutta_1: So imesaṁ sattannaṁ vatapadānaṁ samādānahetu lābhaggappatto ceva yasaggappatto ca vajjigāme.
65971.example_1: And it was due to undertaking these seven vows that he had reached the peak of material things and fame.

59591.comments: In the contextual sentence, it explains the reason for achieving material success and fame through undertaking certain vows.
59591.sutta_1: So imesaṁ sattannaṁ vatapadānaṁ samādānahetu lābhaggappatto ceva yasaggappatto ca vajjigāme.
59591.example_1: And it was due to undertaking these seven vows that he had reached the peak of material things and fame.

12864.COMMENTS: In the contextual sentence, the speaker expresses regret for having offended a holy man, showing the word's usage in a religious context of moral transgression.
12864.example_1: ‘I’ve offended the holy man, the perfected one, the ascetic.

44377.comments: In the contextual sentence, parihita describes someone who will soon be clothed (dressed in regular garments) after abandoning ascetic practices, marking a significant transition in lifestyle.
44377.sutta_1: sādhurūpo ayaṁ samaṇoti, so nacirasseva parihito sānucāriko vicaranto odanakummāsaṁ bhuñjamāno sabbāneva vesāliyāni cetiyāni samatikkamitvā yasā nihīno kālaṁ karissatī’ti.
44377.example_1: will shortly be clothed, living with a partner, eating rice and porridge, having gone past all the shrines near Vesālī. And he will die after losing all his fame.’

62260.meaning_1: with a partner; with a companion
62260.comments: In the contextual sentence, sānucāriko refers to living with a partner or companion, suggesting a state of no longer being solitary.
62260.sutta_1: sādhurūpo ayaṁ samaṇoti, so nacirasseva parihito sānucāriko vicaranto odanakummāsaṁ bhuñjamāno sabbāneva vesāliyāni cetiyāni samatikkamitvā yasā nihīno kālaṁ karissatī’ti.
62260.example_1: will shortly be clothed, living with a partner, eating rice and porridge, having gone past all the shrines near Vesālī. And he will die after losing all his fame.’

76423.comments: In the contextual sentence, nihīna describes someone who has fallen from fame or status, indicating complete ruination.
76423.sutta_1: sādhurūpo ayaṁ samaṇoti, so nacirasseva parihito sānucāriko vicaranto odanakummāsaṁ bhuñjamāno sabbāneva vesāliyāni cetiyāni samatikkamitvā yasā nihīno kālaṁ karissatī’ti.
76423.example_1: will shortly be clothed, living with a partner, eating rice and porridge, having gone past all the shrines near Vesālī. And he will die after losing all his fame.’

53828.comments: The contextual sentence shows this word describing someone who has fallen from fame (yasā nihīno) and will meet an inglorious end.
53828.example_1: mā te ahosi dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāya. yaṃ kho panetaṃ, sunakkhatta, maññasi acelaṃ kaḷāramaṭṭakaṃ, sādhurūpo ayaṃ [arahaṃ] samaṇoti, so nacirasseva parihito sānucāriko vicaranto odanakummāsaṃ bhuñjamāno sabbāneva vesāliyāni cetiyāni samatikkamitvā yasā nihīno [yasānikiṇṇo] kālaṃ karissatīti.

921.meaning_1: case of the naked ascetic Pāthikaputta
921.comments: This term refers to a specific case or account involving the naked ascetic Pāthikaputta, as mentioned in the Dīgha Nikāya. The compound combines terms for "naked ascetic" (acela), the proper name Pāthikaputta, and "case/account" (vatthu).

45306.comments: The contextual sentence shows this refers to a specific naked ascetic (acela) named Pāṭikaputta who was contemporary with the Buddha.
45306.example_1: ekamidāhaṃ, bhaggava, samayaṃ tattheva vesāliyaṃ viharāmi mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ. tena kho pana samayena acelo pāthikaputto [pāṭikaputto] vesāliyaṃ paṭivasati lābhaggappatto ceva yasaggappatto ca vajjigāme. so vesāliyaṃ parisati evaṃ vācaṃ bhāsati, samaṇopi gotamo ñāṇavādo, ahampi ñāṇavādo.

59270.meaning_1: having surpassed; having overcome; having gone beyond; having transcended
59270.comments: In the contextual sentence, samatikkamitvā describes the action of passing by or going beyond all the shrines near Vesālī.
59270.sutta_1: sādhurūpo ayaṁ samaṇoti, so nacirasseva parihito sānucāriko vicaranto odanakummāsaṁ bhuñjamāno sabbāneva vesāliyāni cetiyāni samatikkamitvā yasā nihīno kālaṁ karissatī’ti.
59270.example_1: will shortly be clothed, living with a partner, eating rice and porridge, having gone past all the shrines near Vesālī. And he will die after losing all his fame.’

32156.meaning_1: to show off; to exhibit; to present
32156.comments: In the contextual sentence, dassetuṃ refers to demonstrating superhuman psychic powers as proof of knowledge
32156.sutta_1: Ñāṇavādo kho pana ñāṇavādena arahati uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṁ dassetuṁ.
32156.example_1: One who speaks from knowledge ought to display a superhuman demonstration of psychic power to another who speaks from knowledge.

15594.comments: In the contextual sentence, upaḍḍhapatha refers to meeting someone midway, both literally and metaphorically, suggesting a compromise or mutual effort.
15594.sutta_1: Samaṇo gotamo upaḍḍhapathaṁ āgaccheyya, ahampi upaḍḍhapathaṁ gaccheyyaṁ.
15594.example_1: If the ascetic Gotama meets me half-way,

29846.comments: In the contextual sentence, it refers to performing double the number of psychic feats compared to someone else.
29846.sutta_1: Iti yāvatakaṁ yāvatakaṁ samaṇo gotamo uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṁ karissati, taddiguṇaṁ taddiguṇāhaṁ karissāmī’ti.
29846.example_1: However many demonstrations of psychic power the ascetic Gotama performs, I’ll perform double.’

11187.comments: In the contextual sentence, āgantuṃ is used to express the impossibility of Pāṭikaputta meeting the Buddha unless he abandons his wrong views.
11187.sutta_1: ‘abhabbo kho, sunakkhatta, acelo pāthikaputto taṁ vācaṁ appahāya taṁ cittaṁ appahāya taṁ diṭṭhiṁ appaṭinissajjitvā mama sammukhībhāvaṁ āgantuṁ.
11187.example_1: ‘Sunakkhatta, the naked ascetic Pāṭikaputta is not capable of meeting me face to face, unless he gives up that statement and that intention, and lets go of that view.

18645.COMMENTS: The contextual sentence shows odhārita being used to describe a statement that has been categorically asserted by the Buddha.
18645.sutta_1: ‘Bhagavatā cassa, bhante, esā vācā ekaṁsena odhāritā—
18645.example_1: ‘Sir, the Buddha has categorically asserted that

19106.comments: In the contextual sentence, the word is used in the phrase "bhagavatā cassa, bhante, esā vācā ekaṃsena odhāritā [ovāditā]" meaning "this statement was decisively advised by the Blessed One". The variant reading odhāritā suggests a semantic connection with holding firmly or deciding.
19106.example_1: kiṃ pana maṃ tvaṃ, sunakkhatta, evaṃ vadesi, rakkhatetaṃ, bhante, bhagavā vācaṃ, rakkhatetaṃ sugato vācanti? bhagavatā cassa, bhante, esā vācā ekaṃsena odhāritā [ovāditā], abhabbo acelo pāthikaputto taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā mama sammukhībhāvaṃ āgantuṃ. sacepissa evamassa, ahaṃ taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvā samaṇassa gotamassa sammukhībhāvaṃ gaccheyyanti, muddhāpi tassa vipateyyāti.

1187.meaning_1: name of a Licchavi military general
1187.comments: The contextual sentence shows Ajita as a Licchavi general who was reborn in hell, illustrating the karmic consequences even for powerful figures.
1187.example_1: ‘Ajita the Licchavi general has been reborn in the Great Hell.’

13656.meaning_1: discussion about the miracle of psychic power
13656.comments: The contextual sentence shows this term refers to a specific section in DN24 discussing demonstrations of psychic powers.

5522.comments: In the contextual sentence, "anekasahassā" is used to describe a very large assembly, emphasizing its size by quantifying it as "many thousands." The compound combines "aneka" (many) with "sahassa" (thousand) to form an adjective.
5522.sutta_1: Sā esā, bhaggava, parisā mahā hoti anekasatā anekasahassā.
5522.example_1: That assembly was large, Bhaggava; there were many hundreds, many thousands of them.

30653.meaning_1: name of a wandering ascetics' monastery
30653.comments: The name refers to a specific monastery associated with wandering ascetics, likely named after a distinctive ebony tree stump on its grounds.
30653.sutta_1: Atha kho, bhaggava, acelo pāthikaputto bhīto saṁviggo lomahaṭṭhajāto yena tindukakhāṇuparibbājakārāmo tenupasaṅkami.
30653.example_1: In fear he went to the Pale-Moon Ebony Trunk Monastery of the wanderers.

69989.meaning_1: to get up; to rise; to stand up
69989.comments: In the contextual sentence, vuṭṭhātuṃ is used to express the inability to rise from a seated position, showing the basic meaning of "to stand up" with the added prefix [v] (possibly for emphasis or phonetic reasons).
69989.sutta_1: Evaṁ vutte, bhaggava, acelo pāthikaputto ‘āyāmi, āvuso, āyāmi, āvuso’ti vatvā tattheva saṁsappati, na sakkoti āsanāpi vuṭṭhātuṁ.
69989.example_1: When he had spoken, Pāṭikaputta said: ‘I’m coming, sir, I’m coming!’ But wriggle as he might, he couldn’t get up from his seat.

45932.comments: The contextual sentence shows pāvaḷā refers to the buttocks in a humorous exchange about someone being stuck to a bench.
45932.sutta_1: ‘kiṁ su nāma te, āvuso pāthikaputta, pāvaḷā su nāma te pīṭhakasmiṁ allīnā, pīṭhakaṁ su nāma te pāvaḷāsu allīnaṁ?
45932.example_1: ‘What’s up, Reverend Pāṭikaputta? Is your bottom stuck to the bench, or is the bench stuck to your bottom?

43110.comments: In the contextual sentence, the term describes Pāṭikaputta as being in a state of disgrace or humiliation after losing a challenge.

55837.comments: The contextual sentence shows this term refers to a high-ranking official among the Licchavi clan who addresses an assembly, indicating a position of authority.
55837.sutta_1: Atha kho, bhaggava, aññataro licchavimahāmatto uṭṭhāyāsanā taṁ parisaṁ etadavoca:
55837.example_1: Then, Bhaggava, a certain Licchavi minister stood up and said to the assembly,

25387.meaning_1: yoke of oxen; team of oxen
25387.comments: In the contextual sentence, goyugehi refers to the instrument (with a team of oxen) used for dragging Pāṭikaputta.
25387.sutta_1: mayaṁ acelaṁ pāthikaputtaṁ varattāhi bandhitvā goyugehi āviñcheyyāmāti, tā varattā chijjeyyuṁ pāthikaputto vā.
25387.example_1: “Let’s bind Pāṭikaputta with straps and drag him with a pair of oxen!” But either the straps will break or Pāṭikaputta will.’

27623.comments: In the contextual sentence, chijjeyyuṁ is the optative passive form, showing the potential breaking of straps when attempting to drag Pāṭikaputta.
27623.sutta_1: mayaṁ acelaṁ pāthikaputtaṁ varattāhi bandhitvā goyugehi āviñcheyyāmāti, tā varattā chijjeyyuṁ pāthikaputto vā.
27623.example_1: “Let’s bind Pāṭikaputta with straps and drag him with a pair of oxen!” But either the straps will break or Pāṭikaputta will.’

80549.COMMENTS: In the contextual sentence, kappesi refers to the lion king preparing or arranging his dwelling near a certain thicket.
80549.sutta_1: Atha kho, āvuso, so sīho migarājā aññataraṁ vanasaṇḍaṁ nissāya āsayaṁ kappesi.
80549.example_1: And so that’s what he did.

67549.comments: In the contextual sentence, vijambhi describes the action of stretching after rising from rest, showing a natural bodily movement.
67549.sutta_1: Tatrāsayaṁ kappetvā sāyanhasamayaṁ āsayā nikkhami, āsayā nikkhamitvā vijambhi, vijambhitvā samantā catuddisā anuvilokesi, samantā catuddisā anuviloketvā tikkhattuṁ sīhanādaṁ nadi, tikkhattuṁ sīhanādaṁ naditvā gocarāya pakkāmi.

5460.comments: In the contextual sentence, the Buddha looks around in all four directions before roaring his lion's roar. The aorist form indicates a completed action of surveying the surroundings.
5460.sutta_1: Tatrāsayaṁ kappetvā sāyanhasamayaṁ āsayā nikkhami, āsayā nikkhamitvā vijambhi, vijambhitvā samantā catuddisā anuvilokesi, samantā catuddisā anuviloketvā tikkhattuṁ sīhanādaṁ nadi, tikkhattuṁ sīhanādaṁ naditvā gocarāya pakkāmi.

35561.comments: In the contextual sentence, nadi is used to describe the lion roaring three times (tikkhattuṁ sīhanādaṁ nadi).
35561.sutta_1: Tatrāsayaṁ kappetvā sāyanhasamayaṁ āsayā nikkhami, āsayā nikkhamitvā vijambhi, vijambhitvā samantā catuddisā anuvilokesi, samantā catuddisā anuviloketvā tikkhattuṁ sīhanādaṁ nadi, tikkhattuṁ sīhanādaṁ naditvā gocarāya pakkāmi.

1393.construction: adhi > adhy > ajjh + upa + i + a
1393.comments: In the contextual sentence, the word describes the action of returning to the same resting place after hunting.
1393.sutta_1: So varaṁ varaṁ migasaṅghe vadhitvā mudumaṁsāni mudumaṁsāni bhakkhayitvā tameva āsayaṁ ajjhupesi.

67406.meaning_1: enlarged on the remains (of); fat on the scraps (of)
67406.comments: The contextual sentence shows this adjective describing a jackal who became strong by feeding on the lion's leftovers, illustrating the literal meaning of growing fat on another's scraps.
67406.sutta_1: Tasseva kho, āvuso pāthikaputta, sīhassa migarañño vighāsasaṁvaḍḍho jarasiṅgālo ditto ceva balavā ca.
67406.example_1: Now, there was an old jackal who had grown fat on the lion’s leavings, becoming arrogant and strong.

28024.comments: The word appears in DN24 describing an old jackal comparing itself to a lion king. The compound is a kammadhāraya (descriptive compound) where jara (old) describes sigāla (jackal).
28024.example_1: 28. tasseva kho, āvuso pāthikaputta, sīhassa migarañño vighāsasaṃvaḍḍho jarasiṅgālo [jarasigālo] ditto ceva balavā ca. atha kho, āvuso, tassa jarasiṅgālassa etadahosi, ko cāhaṃ, ko sīho migarājā.

4427.COMMENTS: In the contextual sentence, the word refers to the act of following in someone else's footsteps, showing the intensive/repetitive aspect of the action.

67405.comments: In the contextual sentence, vighāsa refers to leftover food scraps that have caused someone to grow fat.
67405.example_1: seeing himself grown fat on scraps,

60153.comments: In the contextual sentence, samekkhiya is used to mean "seeing" or "perceiving" oneself in a particular state (grown fat on scraps). The gerund form indicates this is an action prior to the main verb.
60153.example_1: seeing himself grown fat on scraps,

50258.COMMENTS: In the contextual sentence, "bheke" refers to frogs being eaten, showing the word in accusative plural form.
50258.example_1: ‘Gorged on frogs, and mice from the barn,

23567.comments: The contextual sentence shows khalamūsikāyo (plural) being eaten along with frogs, emphasizing its literal meaning as a type of rodent found in agricultural settings.
23567.example_1: ‘Gorged on frogs, and mice from the barn,

23031.comments: In the contextual sentence, koṇapāni refers to carcasses or dead bodies tossed in a cemetery.
23031.example_1: and carcasses tossed in the cemetery,

22797.meaning_1: corpse; carcass; dead body; disgusting thing
22797.comments: In the contextual sentence, kūṇapāni refers to discarded carcasses or foul objects thrown in the forest, aligning with both meanings of corpse and disgusting thing.
22797.example_1:
bhutvāna bheke [bhiṅge] khalamūsikāyo,
kaṭasīsu khittāni ca koṇapāni [kūṇapāni],
mahāvane suññavane vivaḍḍho,
amaññi kotthu migarājāhamasmi.

63743.COMMENTS: In the contextual sentence, suññavane is locative singular, describing the location where someone is thriving. The compound emphasizes the uninhabited nature of the forest.
63743.example_1: thriving in the great, empty wood,

69521.comments: In the contextual sentence, vivaḍḍho describes thriving in the great empty wood (Mahāvane suññavane).
69521.example_1: thriving in the great, empty wood,

15224.comments: In the contextual sentence, uddharitvā describes the action of lifting a pot full of gold from water, showing both the source (ablative) and object (accusative) relationships.
15224.sutta_1: Atha kho taṁ, ānanda, gahapatiratanaṁ ubhohi hatthehi udakaṁ omasitvā pūraṁ hiraññasuvaṇṇassa kumbhiṁ uddharitvā rājānaṁ mahāsudassanaṁ etadavoca:
15224.example_1: Then that householder-treasure, immersing both hands in the water, pulled up a pot full of gold, both coined and uncoined, and said to the king,

35258.meaning_1: having smoked; having emitted fumes; having smouldered
35258.comments: In the contextual sentence, the word describes the action of emitting smoke/fumes after creating a blazing fire (pajjalitvā). The absolutive form indicates a completed action preceding the main verb paccuṭṭhāsiṃ.
35258.example_1: 34. atha khvāhaṃ, bhaggava, taṃ parisaṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandassesiṃ samādapesiṃ samuttejesiṃ sampahaṃsesiṃ, taṃ parisaṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandassetvā samādapetvā samuttejetvā sampahaṃsetvā mahābandhanā mokkhaṃ karitvā caturāsītipāṇasahassāni mahāviduggā uddharitvā tejodhātuṃ samāpajjitvā sattatālaṃ vehāsaṃ abbhuggantvā aññaṃ sattatālampi acciṃ [aggiṃ] abhinimminitvā pajjalitvā dhūmāyitvā  [dhūpāyitvā] mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ paccuṭṭhāsiṃ.

39700.COMMENTS: In the contextual sentence, pajānanā refers to the Tathāgata's understanding that leads to nibbāna without misapprehension.
39700.sutta_1: tañca tathāgato pajānāti, tato ca uttaritaraṁ pajānāti; tañca pajānanaṁ na parāmasati, aparāmasato cassa paccattaññeva nibbuti viditā.
39700.example_1: He understands this, and what goes beyond this. And since he does not misapprehend that understanding, he has realized quenching within himself.

1726.comments: In the contextual sentence from DN24, this term refers to the explanatory commentary that helps understand the text without clinging to views.
1726.example_1: aggaññañcāhaṃ, bhaggava, pajānāmi. tañca pajānāmi [tañcapajānāmīti idaṃ syāpotthakenatthi], tato ca uttaritaraṃ pajānāmi, tañca pajānaṃ [pajānanaṃ aṭṭhakathāsaṃvaṇṇanā passitabbā] na parāmasāmi, aparāmasato ca me paccattaññeva nibbuti viditā, yadabhijānaṃ tathāgato no anayaṃ āpajjati.

53736.meaning_1: directly knowing which; which knowing for oneself
53736.comments: In the contextual sentence, this refers to the Tathāgata's direct knowledge that prevents him from coming to ruin.
53736.sutta_1: Tañca pajānāmi, tato ca uttaritaraṁ pajānāmi, tañca pajānaṁ na parāmasāmi, aparāmasato ca me paccattaññeva nibbuti viditā, yadabhijānaṁ tathāgato no anayaṁ āpajjati.
53736.example_1: I understand this, and what goes beyond it. Yet since I do not misapprehend that understanding, I have realized quenching within myself. Directly knowing this, the Realized One does not come to ruin.

13890.meaning_1: creation by a supreme being; divine creation; act of God
13890.comments: In the contextual sentence, issarakutta refers to the theological concept of creation by a supreme deity, contrasted with other theories of creation like brahmakutta (creation by Brahma). The compound combines issara (lord) + kutta (creation).
13890.sutta_1: Santi, bhaggava, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā issarakuttaṁ brahmakuttaṁ ācariyakaṁ aggaññaṁ paññapenti.
13890.example_1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who describe the origin of the world in their tradition as created by the God Almighty, by the Divinity.

48909.meaning_1: created by god; made by Brahma
48909.COMMENTS: In the contextual sentence, this term is used to describe the origin of the world as being created by Brahma, showing its theological significance in describing divine creation.
48909.sutta_1: Santi, bhaggava, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā issarakuttaṁ brahmakuttaṁ ācariyakaṁ aggaññaṁ paññapenti.
48909.example_1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who describe the origin of the world in their tradition as created by the God Almighty, by the Divinity.

19849.meaning_1: how arranged; how constituted; how fashioned
19849.comments: In the contextual sentence, it refers to questioning how the origin of the world is arranged or constituted according to a particular tradition.
19849.sutta_1: ‘kathaṁvihitakaṁ pana tumhe āyasmanto issarakuttaṁ brahmakuttaṁ ācariyakaṁ aggaññaṁ paññapethā’ti?
19849.example_1: ‘But how do you describe in your tradition that the origin of the world came about as created by the God Almighty, by the Divinity?’

57357.COMMENTS: In the contextual sentence from DN24, sañjitā appears in a list of epithets of Brahmā, emphasizing his role as creator of beings. The form sajjitā is a variant spelling.
57357.example_1: 39. tatrāvuso, yo so satto paṭhamaṃ upapanno, tassa evaṃ hoti, ahamasmi brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī issaro kattā nimmātā seṭṭho sajitā [sañjitā, sajjitā] vasī pitā bhūtabhabyānaṃ, mayā ime sattā nimmitā. taṃ kissa hetu?

18207.meaning_1: arranged in this way; constituted thus; so formed
18207.comments: In the contextual sentence, the term is used to question whether the described divine creation of the world matches the tradition being referenced.
18207.sutta_1: Evaṁvihitakaṁ no tumhe āyasmanto issarakuttaṁ brahmakuttaṁ ācariyakaṁ aggaññaṁ paññapethā’ti.
18207.example_1: Is this how you describe in your tradition that the origin of the world came about as created by the God Almighty, by the Divinity?’

52008.meaning_1: Book 2 of the Dīgha Nikāya; Canonical Text of the Great Book
52008.comments: Refers specifically to the second book of the Dīgha Nikāya, containing important suttas like Mahāparinibbānasutta. The contextual sentence shows it being used as a title declaration at the end of the text.
52008.example_1: The canonical text of the Great Division is finished.
